DataElement.preferredName: Local Excision Colorectal Deep Surgical Margin Surgical Margin Status ExcisionColorectalDeepMarginStatus
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.:The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:Extending relatively far inward.:One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A condition or state at a particular time._Status for absence or presence of margin

Concepts.definition: Of or belonging to a restricted area or locality.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.
Extending relatively far inward.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

A condition or state at a particular time.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Invasive Carcinoma Negation Involvement Surgical Margin

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Invasive Carcinoma Negation Involvement Surgical Margin
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.:An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.:A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.
An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
